author: John Cross
title: The world's not against Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola — it just feels that way to him right now
text:
Sport Opinion The world's not against Manchester City boss Pep Guardiola — it just feels that way to him right now It's nonsense to suggest some sort of anti-Blues agenda but you can't dismiss the idea of a man who seems to be having so little fun walking away in the summer Share Guardiola's first season at City wasn't meant to go like this Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The sense of injustice and paranoia is undoubtedly eating away at Pep Guardiola . 
And the real danger is it will destroy him. 
­Guardiola’s anger is consuming him, and once that happens then managers do not work at their best. 
He certainly had a point that Manchester City were hard done by in Saturday's home draw with Tottenham, robbed by a terrible refereeing mistake which spoiled one of their best ­performances of the season. 
But it is just nonsense to suggest that it is anything other than a mistake because there is no agenda against his Blues – even if it seems like that in his mind. 
The Spaniard looks uncomfortable, agitated, surly and you can add frustrated to the mix because their performance against Tottenham deserved a victory. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Guardiola speaks after penalty on Sterling is not given Share this video Watch Next 
You cannot dismiss the idea that if City miss out on the top four – and this season has become a battle for the ­Champions League places, rather than over the title – Guardiola might walk, because he really does not look like he is enjoying himself. 
Spurs boss Mauricio Pochettino insists Guardiola remains one of the best in their business but admits he looks as if he is struggling under the weight of expectation. 
Pochettino says even ­the former Barcelona and Bayern Munich chief is not a miracle-worker and warned he will need time to stamp his authority on the job – but that is the one thing the City boss does not have. 
The Argentine said: “It’s ­difficult to compare him to when I arrived here [replacing Nigel Adkins at Southampton in January 2013], because the expectation was completely different — Guardiola took charge of City after winning 21 trophies with Barcelona and Bayern and I arrived at ­Southampton! The game's key moment see Walker shover Sterling off-balance when clean through... (Photo: AFP/Getty) ...and the referee decide it wasn't worth a penalty and/or a red card (Photo: SilverHub/REX/Shutterstock) 
“It was difficult for people to know who I was or my name. The position was different. 
“But it’s not easy to manage the expectation and you need to settle your ideas and ­philosophy, so you need time. 
“I’m sure Pep will succeed, because he’s one of the best. He’s very emotional and shows it. But this is normal. All the people at Manchester City expect a different position, maybe 10 more points like Chelsea and it’s frustrating. It’s completely different taking charge of Manchester City than it is with Barcelona or Bayern Munich. 
“But he has the ­qualities to show he’s a top manager and with time he’ll show he’s a success here.” 
City did provide a ­tantalising glimpse of what is possible under Guardiola, creating a string of chances in a one-sided first half where keeper Hugo Lloris denied them with a string of brilliant saves. It was another tough day at the office for Guardiola... (Photo: Getty) ...as City took just a point from a home match they led 2-0... (Photo: Getty) ...and were denied a seemingly cast-iron penalty (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
But Lloris made big mistakes on two goals within nine minutes of the restart, first missing the ball when he rushed out to stop Leroy Sane, who went on to score, and then spilling the ball to allow Kevin De Bruyne to fire home from close range. 
Dele Alli pulled Tottenham back into the game after 58 minutes, but the turning point was Kyle Walker’s push on Raheem Sterling in the area. 
If Sterling had gone down, it would have been a penalty. But he was honest, stayed on his feet and then fluffed his shot straight to Lloris. Referee Andre Marriner did not give a spot-kick, and Walker was not sent off. 
It got even worse as, within a minute, Tottenham were level through Son Heung-min. 
City midfielder Yaya Toure admitted the result was another setback and claimed they were robbed of a much-needed victory. Blues fans were all smiles when De Bruyne put them 2-0 up, but the joy did not last (Photo: AMA/Getty) 
Toure said: “We have to win once and after that things will come. People look at the details, the possession we had. But scoring goals is most important. 
“That’s something difficult to take, we feel a little bit robbed because we dominated. It was a fantastic game for us. It’s ­difficult to take because it’s a couple of points going away. 
“Tottenham are strong, they fight in every area but today we deserve the three points. 
“The manager was frustrated afterwards. When you see how many chances we had, ­particularly in the first half, it was ­unbelievable, against a big team like Tottenham. 
“They are one of the top teams this year. The manager and the players were frustrated, because we feel like we’ve been robbed.” poll loading Will Guardiola make Man City champions? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
